title: How to Clean Baked on Grease Off Glass Dishes

steps.title: Coat the bottom of the dish with a liquid soap and baking soda.
steps.content: Coat the bottom of the dish with a liquid soap and baking soda. Using a bottle of standard dish soap, drizzle a cherry-sized amount of cleaner over the greasy parts of the dish. Next, sprinkle at least 1 tsp (6 g) of baking soda over the especially greasy areas. If your glass is completely covered in baked-on grease, feel free to use more baking soda as you see fit. [1] X Research source You can use whatever type of dish soap that you have on hand.

steps.title: Fill the glass dish with hot water.
steps.content: Fill the glass dish with hot water. Fill the bottom of your glass dish with hot water until the dish soap and baking soda are completely covered. Continue pouring until about 1 in (2.5 cm) of the dish is filled. If you’re cleaning a smaller dish, you might not need to use as much water. [2] X Research source Hot water helps wear down old stains like baked-on grease.

steps.title: Wait 15 minutes so the dish can soak.
steps.content: Wait 15 minutes so the dish can soak. Don’t wipe off any grease until you’ve given the dish soap and baking soda enough time to soak. If the baked-on grease stain is especially bad, let the dish soak for at least 30 minutes. [3] X Research source If you want, you can also soak your greasy dishes overnight.

steps.title: Scrub down the greasy spots with an abrasive sponge.
steps.content: Scrub down the greasy spots with an abrasive sponge. Pour the dirty, sudsy water into the sink. Using a clean, abrasive sponge, start rubbing over the stubborn grease spots. Once you’ve cleaned off the baked-on grease, rinse off any leftover residue with warm water. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the bottom of the dish with warm water.
steps.content: Fill the bottom of the dish with warm water. Pour enough water into the dish to cover all of the grease spots. If the baked-on grease is stuck to the sides of the dish, you can add more water. [5] X Research source Don’t use cool water for this, or the grease might not come off.

steps.title: Pour a pea-sized amount of dish soap into the water.
steps.content: Pour a pea-sized amount of dish soap into the water. Drizzle a small amount of soap along the bottom of the dish, so the grease can be soaked away. Next, try spreading the soap around, so entire dish is sudsy. [6] X Research source Any kind of dish soap will work for this process.

steps.title: Place 1 dryer sheet into the glass dish.
steps.content: Place 1 dryer sheet into the glass dish. Place the item on top of the water, so it can float in the center of the dish. If you’re cleaning an especially large item, consider soaking multiple dryer sheets in the sudsy water. [7] X Research source Similar to the dish soap, the chemicals in the dryer sheet help to work away the grease from the dish.

steps.title: Leave the sheet in the glassware for at least 10 minutes.
steps.content: Leave the sheet in the glassware for at least 10 minutes. Set a timer, then step away from the soaking dish. Don’t try to scrub or rinse out the dish; instead, give the grease time to loosen and soak. After 10 minutes pass, remove the dryer sheets and toss them out. [8] X Research source If you remove the dryer sheet right away, you won’t notice a difference.

steps.title: Wipe off the baked on grease with a sponge.
steps.content: Wipe off the baked on grease with a sponge. Take an abrasive sponge and scrub over the baked-on grease spots. Use short, quick motions to coax the grease off your dish, until you’ve removed all the residue. Continue scrubbing the bottom surface and edges of the dish to completely clean off the dish. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Combine baking soda and white vinegar to clean the surface.
steps.content: Combine baking soda and white vinegar to clean the surface. Sprinkle a small amount of baking soda along the bottom and sides of your glass dish, focusing on the especially greasy areas. After filling a small spray bottle with white vinegar, spritz over the baking soda. Let the dish sit overnight, then wipe away any excess vinegar and baking soda the following day. [10] X Research source You can repeat this process as many times as necessary.

steps.title: Scrub the dish with a Magic Eraser if you don’t mind using some elbow grease.
steps.content: Scrub the dish with a Magic Eraser if you don’t mind using some elbow grease. Take an unused cleaning sponge or Magic Eraser and soak it under the faucet. Using long, forceful movements, rub the areas of the dish that have a lot of baked-on grease. Keep scrubbing the glass until the patches of grease are completely gone! [11] X Research source You might need more than 1 Magic Eraser to clean out your dish, depending on how bad the grease stains are.

steps.title: Mix at least 2 denture tablets with hot water to get rid of grease.
steps.content: Mix at least 2 denture tablets with hot water to get rid of grease. Fill your glass dish about halfway with hot water. Next, drop at least 2 denture tablets into the water. Wait at least 3 hours before emptying the dish into the sink. Then, wash it as usual. [12] X Research source If your dish has a lot of greasy spots, consider letting your glassware soak overnight. For a stronger cleaning solution, add in 3 denture tablets.

steps.title: Brush toothpaste over any problem areas with a toothbrush.
steps.content: Brush toothpaste over any problem areas with a toothbrush. Squeeze a pea-sized amount of regular toothpaste onto a greasy area of your dish. Using a soft-bristled toothbrush, scrub over the toothpaste to get rid of the baked-on grease. Once the dish is completely clean, rinse it out with dish soap and warm water. [13] X Research source
